questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lignin Lignin a complex organic polymer present in abundant quantities in plant secondary cell wall. It is a major Insoluble Dietary Fiber. It is not a Carbohydrate. It is a Poly phenolic compound, a polymer of Phenyl propane. Due to its non-polar nature it is not soluble in water. Inulin, amylose and chitin are homopolysaccharides made up of frutose, glucose and N-acetylglucosamine monomeric subunits respectively. Due to the presence of polar groups such as -OH, -COOH these are partly soluble in water.

Solution:

L arginine NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells. The vasodilator – nitroglycerin also enters smooth muscle cells, where its metabolism also leads to the formation of NO. Extra information: NO synthase There are three isoforms of NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) nNOS - neuronal iNOS- inducible eNOS- endothelial EC no. 1 (oxido-reductase) Mono oxygenase (one oxygen is added in substrate) Usually belongs to EC no 4 but NO synthase is an exception.

questions.text: Given below is the parameters of ABG analysis. pH 7.2, HCO3 -10 mEq/ L, PCO2 -30mm Hg. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic acidosis A disorder resulting from a primary fall in bicarbonate level (HCO 3 ) (< 22 mEq/L) resulting in a decreased pH of arterial plasma (< pH 7.35). This happens because of decreased ratio for bicarbonate concentration to pCO2 (normal level is 35-45 mmHg) is called as metabolic acidosis. In respiratory acidosis there is increase of both bicarbonate level (HCO 3 ) and pCO 2 above normal.

questions.text: 50-year-old male presented with tachypnea, confusion, blood glucose 350mg/dl and pH 7.0. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic acidosis High Blood glucose indicates diabetic condition which will cause ketone body production which is cause of decrease in pH due to their acidic nature. A disorder resulting in a decreased pH of arterial plasma (< pH 7.35) due to a defective metabolism is called as metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following vitamin causes this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Niacin deficiency This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency . Niacin is formed from tryptophan amino acid. So, tryptophan deficiency can also lead to Casal’s necklace. 60 mg tryptophan gets converted to 1 mg Niacin.

questions.text: Urine turns black on standing in case of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homogentisate oxidase deficiency – alkaptonuria In patients of Alkaptonuria with deficiency of Homogentisate dioxygenase/ oxidase (requires Iron), fresh urine is normal in colour; but on standing or on exposion to air urine turns Black. It’s because homogentisic acid accumulated in urine gets oxidised by oxygen in air and gives rise to black colored benzoquinone acetic acid.

questions.text: What is the mucopolysaccharide/proteoglycan present in glomerular basement membrane?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heparan sulfate Heparan sulfate is present in basement membrane of glomerulus. Also, it is present on cell surfaces and has a role in retinal cell-cell attachment.

questions.text: Which enzyme is active during low insulin glucagon ratio?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucose 6 phosphatase Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis , which occurs during fasting. Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state. Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin. Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

options.label: A
options.text: Primary, secondary, tertiary structure are destroyed by denaturation.

options.label: C
options.text: Secondary structure stabilised by disulphide bridges.

options.label: D
options.text: Secondary and tertiary structures depends on amino acids

questions.correct_answer: D. Secondary and tertiary structures depends on amino acids
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary and tertiary structures depends on amino acids Disulfide bond is not present in 2° structure, but is present in tertiary structure. 1° structure is not destroyed by denaturation. 2°& 3° structures are based on amino acid sequence, Infact the overall protein structure depends upon amino acid sequence. Even change of one amino acid can affect the overall structure & function of protein. Secondary structure is not the three-dimensional structure of protein. The overall 3D structure of a polypeptide is called its tertiary structure. Tertiary structure is due to overall interactions between the R groups of amino acids. Secondary structure is due to local interactions between stretches of a polypeptide chain.

questions.text: In preterm infants with RDS, which is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open.. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with paresthesia, Hb = 6.8 gms%, peripheral smear–macrocytes and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei and atropic gastritis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B12 deficiency The symptoms presented here are all indicative of megaloblastic anemia which is mainly caused due to deficiency of Vitamin B12 or folate.

questions.text: Which of the following binds to the tyrosine kinase receptors,
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insulin The insulin and IGF-I receptors have intrinsic ligand-activated tyrosine kinase activity. By binding to these receptors, these hormones will activate tyrosine kinases inside the cell which in turn phosphorylates important enzymes for involved in a number of processes such as metabolism, growth and differentiation and also inflammatory response. Glucagon binds to G- protein coupled receptors. Leptin binds to cytokine receptor while thyroxine binds to nuclear receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: both Vmax and Km are decreased

options.label: D
options.text: Km is usually increased, Vmax is reduced

questions.correct_answer: A. Vmax decreases, Km remains constant
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vmax decreases, Km remains constant In Non-Competitive Inhibition: Inhibitor binds at regulatory site of the enzyme and induces changes in the active site so that substrate cannot bind and thus decreases the velocity of the reaction. But there is no change in Km or Substrate concentration. Km is increased in case of competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds at the active site.

questions.text: Amino acid which absorbs UV light at 280 nm
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tryptophan Proteins and amino acids absorb UV-light at 280 nm, due to aromatic nature of these amino acids &they have conjugated double bonds in the rings. Maximum absorption occurs by tryptophan as it has 2 rings in its side chain

Solution:

RNA editing In liver cell, Apo B 100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B 48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B 100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification. RNA splicing is also a post transcriptional modification but this is removal of introns and not editing. RNA interference is silencing technique where the gene is silenced by not letting the product of gene formed. Translocation occurs during translation. This is movement of ribosome over mRNA.

questions.text: Adenosine is 28%, what is the % of cytosine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

22% By chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine, as they pair with each other by two hydrogen bonds. As adenosine given is 28 %, so total A+T is 56%. Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds. Remaining 44% equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

questions.text: Which factor in warfarin therapy, have decreased gamma carboxylation of glutamate residue
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor II Vitamin K is required for activation of clotting factors - 2,7,9 & 10. Warfarin is a competitive inhibitor of enzyme epoxide reductase required for vitamin K cycle; hence It will inhibit vitamin k function in turn will affect the clotting factor II (prothrombin) activation.
